messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] New Movie With -- surprisingly! -- Unschooling Po...
messages.msgSnippet: ... Yes, I would agree, though no one turns out to be all-good or all-bad, even the heroine. It s a messy journey in which everyone disappoints themselves and
messages.messageBody:
mummy124@... writes:


> I was just reading a review of the movie and saw the homeschooling part
> too.
> Had intended to write in and ask if anyone saw it. What the review I read
> said the lead character shows strength and doesn't become the shrinking
> violet. I thought that was a good sign for homeschoolers. We will probably
> wait for the dvd but I'll put it on my list just the same.
>

Yes, I would agree, though no one turns out to be all-good or all-bad,
even the heroine. It's a messy journey in which everyone disappoints
themselves and others, yet they each find ways to break through and become more
"real." The end is kinda "Breakfast Club" in feel.

I wonder if those of us who were schooled ourselves but now have
unschooled awhile will actually appreciate it more (or on more levels) than those
who can only see it from inside the school perspective. I think the social webs
schoolkids weave might have such emotional resonance that those people will
take the movie literally, and maybe miss the metaphorical (or allegorical or
whatever) layers. JJ


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
